title: The Crucifixion of Christ
shortSummary: Mark 15 details the trial, suffering, crucifixion, death, and burial of Jesus Christ. This chapter reveals the fulfillment of prophecy and the sacrificial love of Jesus, who willingly endured humiliation and death to atone for humanity's sins.
timeline: c. AD 30 - The Passion Week, culminating in the crucifixion of Jesus

keyCharacters.name: Jesus Christ
keyCharacters.description: The Son of God and Messiah who is tried, mocked, crucified, and buried in this chapter, fulfilling Old Testament prophecy.

keyCharacters.name: Pontius Pilate
keyCharacters.description: The Roman governor who questions Jesus, finds no fault in Him, but ultimately condemns Him to crucifixion to appease the crowd.

keyCharacters.name: Barabbas
keyCharacters.description: A prisoner guilty of insurrection and murder, whom the crowd chooses to release instead of Jesus.

keyCharacters.name: Joseph of Arimathaea
keyCharacters.description: A respected council member who boldly requests Jesus’ body from Pilate and provides a tomb for His burial.

keyCharacters.name: Mary Magdalene
keyCharacters.description: A devoted follower of Jesus who witnesses His crucifixion and burial.

definitions.definition: The governor’s official residence or headquarters where Jesus was mocked and questioned.
To be whipped or flogged as a form of punishment, which Jesus endured before crucifixion.
The place of the skull; the site outside Jerusalem where Jesus was crucified.
The day before the Sabbath, when preparations were made for the Sabbath rest.
The thick curtain separating the Holy of Holies from the rest of the temple, symbolizing access to God.

outline.heading: Jesus Before Pilate and the Crowd’s Choice
outline.description: Jesus is brought before Pilate, questioned about His kingship, and despite Pilate’s reluctance, the crowd demands His crucifixion and the release of Barabbas. This reveals the rejection of Jesus as King and the fulfillment of divine justice.

outline.heading: Mockery and Preparation for Crucifixion
outline.description: Roman soldiers mock Jesus by dressing Him in purple and crowning Him with thorns, highlighting His suffering and humiliation as the King of the Jews.

outline.heading: The Crucifixion at Golgotha
outline.description: Jesus is led to Golgotha, crucified between two thieves, and mocked by onlookers and religious leaders, fulfilling prophecy and demonstrating His identification with sinners.

outline.heading: Jesus’ Death and Its Significance
outline.description: Darkness covers the land, Jesus cries out in abandonment, then dies; the temple veil tears, and a Roman centurion declares Him the Son of God, affirming His divine identity and the atoning nature of His death.

outline.heading: Jesus’ Burial
outline.description: Devoted women witness Jesus’ burial by Joseph of Arimathaea, who provides a tomb, fulfilling the respect due to the Messiah and setting the stage for the resurrection.

application: Trust in Jesus’ sacrificial death as the full payment for your sins and the way to reconciliation with God.
Embrace humility and endure suffering with faith, following Christ’s example of obedience even under unjust circumstances.
Stand boldly for Christ like Joseph of Arimathaea, showing courage and devotion in your faith.
Remember the significance of the torn temple veil as an invitation to approach God directly through Jesus.

keyVerses.text: And so Pilate, willing to content the people, released Barabbas unto them, and delivered Jesus, when he had scourged him, to be crucified.
keyVerses.significance: This verse shows the injustice of Jesus’ condemnation and highlights His willing submission to suffering for humanity’s sake.

keyVerses.text: And when they had crucified him, they parted his garments, casting lots upon them, what every man should take.
keyVerses.significance: This fulfills Old Testament prophecy and emphasizes the humiliation Jesus endured even in death.

keyVerses.text: And at the ninth hour Jesus cried with a loud voice, saying, Eloi, Eloi, lama sabachthani? which is, being interpreted, My God, my God, why hast thou forsaken me?
keyVerses.significance: Jesus expresses the depth of His suffering, fulfilling Psalm 22 and demonstrating His identification with human abandonment.

keyVerses.text: And when the centurion, which stood over against him, saw that he so cried out, and gave up the ghost, he said, Truly this man was the Son of God.
keyVerses.significance: A Gentile soldier’s confession affirms Jesus’ divine identity and the significance of His death.
